assemblage.p: A polynomial is an algebraic expression with several terms. Each term is a power of a variable (or a product of powers) with a constant coefficient.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: The exponents in a polynomial must be whole numbers, which means that a polynomial has no radicals containing variables, and no variables in the denominators of fractions.
Recall that: An algebraic expression with only one term is called a monomial. An expression with two terms is called a binomial, and an expression with three terms is a trinomial.

ul.li: The expression 2x^3 is a monomial (it has only one term).
The expression x^2-16 is a binomial (it has two terms).
The expression ax^2+bx+c is called a quadratic trinomial.

statement.p: Explain the terms monomial, binomial, trinomial, and polynomial.

answer.p: A monomial has one term, a binomial has two terms, a trinomial has three terms, and a polynomial has several terms. Each term is a power of a variable (or a product of powers) with a constant coefficient.

subsection.title: Degree

statement.p: What is the difference between a polynomial of degree four and a polynomial with four terms?

answer.p: Degree four means the largest exponent is four.

subsection.p: Polynomials in one variable are usually written in descending powers of the variable. The term with the largest exponent comes first, then the term with the next highest exponent, and so on down to the constant term, if there is one.

statement.p: Write the polynomial x+3x^4-5-2x^2 in descending powers.

solution.p: We start with the highest power. We must be careful to keep the correct sign of each term.

statement.p: What does it mean to write a polynomial in descending powers?

answer.p: Start with the term with the largest exponent, and continue with decreasing exponents.

subsection.title: Evaluating Polynomials
subsection.p: We evaluate polynomials the same way we evaluate any other algebraic expression: by substituting the given values for the variables and then following the order of operations to simplify.

solution.p: Substitute \alert{\dfrac{3}{2}} for t, and follow the order of operations to simplify.

subsection.title: Like Terms

assemblage.p: Recall that: To add or subtract like terms, we add or subtract their numerical coefficients. The variable factors of the terms remain unchanged.

statement.p: What is the numerical coefficient of a term?

answer.p: The factor in a term that is a constant, not a variable.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: Which of the following two expressions can be simplified? 3x^2+5x^3~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~3x^2+5x^2 In the first expression, the two terms have different exponents, even though the base, x, is the same. Powers of the same variable with different exponents are not like terms. The first expression, 3x^2+5x^3, cannot be simplified.
In the second expression, 3x^2 and 5x^2 are like terms.Thus, 3x^2+5x^2=8x^2 Note that we do not change the exponent on x in the sum; it is still 2.

statement.p: Simplify by combining any like terms: x^3+2x^2-2x^3-(-4x^2)+4x

solution.p: The terms x^3 and -2x^3 are like terms; so are 2x^2 and -4x^2. We group the like terms together and combine them. \blert{x^3-2x^3} + \alert{2x^2-(-4x^2)} + 4x = \blert{-x^3} + \alert{6x^2} + 4x The last term, 4x, is not combined with any other terms.

subsection.title: Adding Polynomials
subsection.p: To add two polynomials we remove parentheses and combine like terms.
We can also use a vertical format to add polynomials.

subsection.title: Subtracting Polynomials
subsection.p: If an expression in parentheses is preceded by a minus sign, we must change the sign of each term within parentheses when we remove the parentheses. This rule applies when we subtract polynomials.

warning.p: In Example 9, the following second step is \alert{\text{incorrect}}: 4x^2+2x-5-2x^2-3x-2 because we have not changed the sign of \alert{\text{each}} term inside parentheses.

subsection.p: To use a vertical format for subtraction, we change the sign of each term in the bottom, or subtracted, polynomial.

statement.p: When subtracting two polynomials, what must we do before combining like terms?

answer.p: Change the sign of each term in the subtracted polynomial.

subsection.title: Application
subsection.p: Applied problems may involve addition or subtraction of polynomials. In particular, to calculate the profit it earns by selling its product, a company must subtract the cost of producing the goods from the revenue it earns by selling them. We can state this as a formula.

statement.p:
It costs The Cookie Company 200+2x dollars to produce x bags of cookies per week, and they earn 8x-0.01x^2 dollars from the sale of x bags of cookies.
Write a polynomial for the profit earned by The Cookie Company on x bags of cookies.
Find the company's profit on 300 bags of cookies, and on 600 bags.

li.p: Evaluate the profit polynomial for x=\alert{300} and for x=\blert{600}. For 300 bags of cookies, the profit is -0.01(\alert{300})^2+6(\alert{300})-200 = -900+1800-200=700 or $700. For 600 bags of cookies, the profit is -0.01(\blert{600})^2+6(\blert{600})-200 = -3600+3600-200=-200 The company loses $200 if they produce 600 bags of cookies.
